scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the papers of the Hubard family of Buckingham County, Virginia, ca. 1767-1907, and undated, ca. fifty items, including legal and financial documents, correspondence, invitations, an abstract of Buckingham County votes, an Atlantic and Danville Railway pass, an 1868 Republican ticket, a political pamphlet supporting Edmund W. Hubard, and business letters, especially from Rives and Harris.

Some of the correspondents include: William P. Barksdale (1907 Jun 18); M.R. Cabell (1816 Aug 1); Thomas Dickinson (n.d.); John W. Eppes (n.d.); Dr. W.J. Eppes (1834 Jun 3); Representative Edmund W. Hubard mentions the debate on the civil and diplomatic bill, John C. Calhoun, and Henry Clay, "Clay is now speaking in the Senate on his resolutions. It is not deemed a cinch effort. He seems worn down and dispirited. He will retire before long" (1842 Mar 1) and the Texas annexation question (1845 Jan 14); R.T. Hubard (1852 Sep 21); William J. Hubard (1884 Mar 22; 1907 Jun 24); Jesse Jones re slave hires (1822 Aug 24); Andrew Jackson Montague (1904 Mar 8); Edward Moore concerning the tobacco crop (1886 Dec 30); W[illiam?] P. Moseley (1859 Oct 1); John C. Page (1827 Mar 28); Ellen Wayles Randolph (n.d.); and Louisa H. Randolph (1894 Jul 30).
